title: Compound W and Z - IMFs- zero order- mass spec

content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student investigates properties of two compounds found in food, labeled Compound <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and Compound <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Structures of the compounds are shown below.

(a) Using <math alttext="V S E P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>VSEPR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> theory, predict the <math alttext="O C N" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></math> bond angle indicated by the arrow in the diagram of compound <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

A student investigates properties of two compounds found in food, labeled Compound <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and Compound <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Structures of the compounds are shown below.

(a) Using <math alttext="V S E P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>VSEPR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> theory, predict the <math alttext="O C N" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></math> bond angle indicated by the arrow in the diagram of compound <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(b) List all of the type(s) of intermolecular force(s) that the two compounds have in common.

(c) Compound <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a higher boiling point than compound <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student claims that compound <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a greater boiling point because it has greater London dispersion forces than compound <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>W</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do you agree or disagree with this claim? Justify your answer in terms of the types and relative strengths of intermolecular forces in each substance.

A different compound found in food, compound <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is known to decompose over time. To study the reaction, a student monitors the molar concentration of compound <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a solution at constant temperature. After collecting and analyzing the data, the following linear graph was created by plotting <math alttext="the molar concentration of X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>X</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> versus time.

(d) The student proposes that the reaction is zero order with respect to compound <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer using the data in the graph above.

(e) Write the rate law expression for the decomposition of compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is consistent with the graph above.
(f) Determine the value of the rate constant, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the reaction. Include units with your answer.

(g) The student claims that if the experiment were conducted again at a higher temperature, the value for the rate constant, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, would increase. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer by comparing the slope of the original line above to the slope that would result from the higher temperature conditions.

A student titrates a solution of compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the concentration of <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution. In order to conduct the titration, the student needs to prepare <math alttext="100, decimal point, milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.010 molar, K I O 3, aqueous," display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.010</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><msub><mrow><mtext> KIO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by diluting a <math alttext="0.040 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.040</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> stock solution.
(h) What volume of <math alttext="0.040 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.040</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> stock solution, in <math alttext="milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, would be required to prepare <math alttext="100, decimal point, milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.010 molar, K I O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.010</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><msub><mrow><mtext> KIO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(i) To prepare the diluted solution, the student uses a graduated cylinder to measure the volume of stock solution calculated in part (h) and adds it to a <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask, followed by the addition of distilled water. If the student filled the volumetric flask with distilled water but the bottom of the meniscus was significantly above the <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> mark, would the resulting solution concentration be greater than, less than, or equal to what was intended? Justify your answer.

The <math alttext="I O 3 with a negative 1 charge, aqueous," overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>I</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ion can be reduced to form elemental iodine. Three possible mass spectra for a sample of atomic iodine (<math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) are represented below.

(j) Identify the mass spectrum that most likely represents the isotopes of iodine. Justify your choice.

Iodine can also react with a certain element, <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The successive ionization energy values for element <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are given below.

Ionization Energy (<math alttext="in kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

First
 419

Second
 3051

Third
 4419

Fourth
 5878

Fifth
 7975

(k) What is the charge of the ion formed by element <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in its compounds? Justify your answer using the data in the table.

(l) Given the charge determined in part (k), what is the formula for the compound that element <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> would form with iodine?

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
